name: Eddy Grant
description:
'''Edmond Montague Grant''' (born 5 March 1948) is a [[Guyanese in the United Kingdom|Guyanese-British]] singer, songwriter, musician, and record producer. Noted for his genre-blending style and socially conscious lyrics, he is the creator of the musical genre known as [[ringbang]].

Grant rose to prominence as a founding member of [[the Equals]], one of the UK's first racially mixed bands who are best remembered for the hit song "[[Baby, Come Back (The Equals song)|Baby, Come Back]]" (1967), which Grant wrote and performed lead guitar and backing vocals on. His subsequent solo career spawned songs such as "[[I Don't Wanna Dance (Eddy Grant song)|I Don't Wanna Dance]]" (1982), "[[Electric Avenue]]" (1983), and the [[Anti-Apartheid Movement|anti-apartheid]] anthem "[[Gimme Hope Jo'anna]]" (1988). "Electric Avenue" reached platinum status, became his biggest international hit, and earned a [[Grammy Award]] nomination.
